Ottawa,
January 27, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Your voucher No. 1703 of December 31, 1938, was issued in favour of L. Fouchard Cie.

We are today in receipt of a letter from A. Pineau, Ste. Rose du Lac, Man., returning the cheque for $3.05 and stating that he now owns the business and that the cheque should have been issued in his favour rather than in favour of L. Fouchard Cie. As the original voucher has now gone to the auditor it will be necessary for you to prepare and forward another account in favour of Mr. Pineau. When this is received another cheque will be issued and sent to him to replace the one which he has returned.

Yours truly,

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

DAUPHIN, August 29th, 1939.

Hon. T. A. Crerar,
Minister of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Ebb and Flow School

Dear Mr. Crerar:

The accommodation for the teacher, who is married with a family, at the above school, is certainly not adequate for a family. It is simply two small rooms, a part of the school building, and I understand that the Indian Agent for Manitoba did some time ago, recommend the building of an addition to the school to be used as part of the residence.

The purpose of this letter is mainly to acquaint you with the facts and to advise you that I know the situation at Ebb & Flow very well and there is very real need of additional living accommodation, and that if it is at all possible, something should be done before the coming winter. I think that a lean-to about 12 feet wide, and the width of the school, would be just about right with the accommodation already provided. By a reference to Mr. Waite, your Indian Agent at Portage la Prairie, you could ascertain further facts regarding this situation.

Thanking you in advance for your usual prompt attention, I remain,

Yours very truly,

(sgd.) W. J. Ward, M.P.

Ottawa, September 7, 1939.

Dear Sir:

In a report to the Department dated November 23, 1938, you intimated that the living accommodation at the Ebb and Flow Indian Day School was wholly inadequate for the present teacher and her family.

When Mrs. Adam was appointed as teacher of this school, the appointment was made on the recommendation of Archbishop Sinnott, who intimated that a married teacher might be employed for a year and that later a better arrangement might be made. It might be well if you discussed this matter with Archbishop Sinnott. The Department feels under no obligation to provide living quarters for a married teacher at this school. The present policy is, as you know, to employ only single teachers or women whose husbands are physically incapacitated. It would appear that in this case the husband is a trader outside the reserve.

Your immediate attention to this matter will be very much appreciated.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
532 Dominion Public Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
EX'D.

Ottawa, September 7, 1939.

Re: Request for additional accommodation for teacher, Bob and Flow Indian Day School

Dear Mr. Ward:

I am directed by the Minister to acknowledge receipt of your letter of August 29, in which you state that, in your judgment, the teacher's living quarters at the above noted school are wholly inadequate to accommodate the present teacher and her family.

The records indicate that the present teacher, Mrs. Hilda Mary Adam, was nominated for the position of teacher at the Bob and Flow school by Archbishop Sinnott. The Archbishop was reminded at that time that it was not the policy of the Department to employ married women as teachers, other than those whose husbands were physically incapacitated. Archbishop Sinnott requested, however, that Mrs. Adam be appointed for a year, in the hope that he would be able to make better arrangements the succeeding year. The failure of the Archbishop, however, to nominate a single teacher to take charge of this school would indicate that he has experienced difficulty in securing a suitable teacher for the position.

It is true, as you state, that Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies, in a report dated -

W. J. Ward, Esq., M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6231, file 509-5, part 4)
dated November 28, 1936, expressed the view that the living accommodation at the Bob and Flow school was insufficient for a married man. However, the Department did not feel that we were under any obligation whatever to provide accommodation for the husband of this teacher, who, according to the reports on file here, is a trader, operating just off the reserve.

In view of your representation, Inspector Hamilton will be asked to again report on the accommodation at this particular school and to interview Archbishop Sinnott regarding any thought the Archbishop may have in mind with respect to the nomination of an unmarried teacher. Just as soon as the Inspector's report is received, I shall be glad to communicate with you again.

Yours sincerely,

W. J. F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.

W. J. Ward, Esq., M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa.
dated November 29, 1938, expressed the view that the living accommodation at the Ebb and Flow school was insufficient for a married man. However, the Department did not feel that we were under any obligation whatever to provide accommodation for the husband of this teacher, who, according to the reports on file here, is a trader, operating just off the reserve.

In view of your representation, Inspector Hamilton will be asked to again report on the accommodation at this particular school and to interview Archbishop Sinnott regarding any thought the Archbishop may have in mind with respect to the nomination of an unmarried teacher. Just as soon as the Inspector's report is received, I shall be glad to communicate with you again.

Yours sincerely,

W. J. F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

Sir,

In Estimates 1939-40 an amount of $471.00 was entered for the erection of an addition to the Ebb and Flow Day School. The addition is to the living quarters of the teacher. I might state that there are only two rooms for the teacher and these are small; they consist of a kitchen and bedroom. There is no accommodation for a visiting official. The present teacher is married and the husband lives at the school. If it is the Department's intention to build this addition this fall the work should be commenced as soon as possible as the season is beginning to get late.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

Complaints have reached the Department that the living quarters for the teacher at the Ebb and Flow Indian Day School are not sufficiently large. Some months ago we wrote to Inspector Hamilton in regard to this matter and he submitted detailed information regarding the material required to enlarge the teacher's living quarters.

I understand that enlarging the building would involve an expenditure of approximately $700.00. In our estimates for the current fiscal year this amount was not specifically included. However, if there is a real necessity for an addition to this building it might be possible to allocate funds for the purpose. Could Indian labour be secured?

I have been informed that the teacher's husband is residing at the school. Is he physically capable of earning a living? If not, what does he do at the school? Is it due to the fact that there are two persons living in the teacher's living quarters that requests are reaching us for enlarged accommodation? An immediate reply would be appreciated.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I am in receipt of Mr. Pratt's memorandum of July 10, with reference to the teacher's residence at the Ebb and Flow Indian Day School.

July 12th,
1941.

Sir,

Re: 126-4-5

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Department letter of June 10th, and regret the delay in answering. This was due to the payment of treaty.

There are two rooms at present in the teacherage which is a part of the school building; the size of the rooms is approximately 12 x 13 each. I suggested that a lean too addition be built 12 x 26. This would give two additional rooms. Indian labour would not be experienced enough without the help of a white foreman. The cramped space is not altogether due to the teacher (Mrs. Adam) being married. There is no family. The husband runs a small store outside the reserve, about one mile from the school. He is apparently physically capable of earning a living. He does no work around the school. Under present conditions the living quarters are too small. They are too small for a single man as there is no extra accommodation for visiting officials. The present arrangement means that the Adams give up their bed to accommodate officials and use the Indian school room as an extra bedroom.

Your obedient servant,

Extract from Inspector Hamilton's letter dated December 16, 1942.

Ebb and Flow Indian Day School

The teacher's living quarters at the rear of the school have been enlarged since my last visit and the accommodation is much better. They now have two bedrooms, a kitchen and dining-room combined, and a living room. The school and residence are badly in need of exterior painting. The old paint has almost entirely disappeared and the building presents a neglected and dismal appearance. I urge that funds be provided to do this work early next spring.
The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.

The season is too far advanced to consider painting before the end of the fiscal year and I beg to request that an amount of $40.00 be made available for this work in the spring.

Indian Agent
Ottawa,

I recently visited the Ebb and Flow Reserve in the Portage Agency, and outside the school they have an over-flowing well, which is making the ground around the well wet and boggy. Cattle are drinking around this well, which makes it very unsanitary.

I took the liberty of giving Mr. Hamilton authority to get the well fixed at once, by digging a ditch away from it and hauling in some stones around the well. This well is cased with a 4 inch iron pipe and when fixed in this way I believe it will be quite satisfactory.

I hope my action meets with your approval.

Dear Mr. Graham:

You are authorized to proceed with the erection of a combined classroom and teacher's residence at the Ebb and Flow Indian Day School, Manitowah agency. October 19th, 1914.

Most Rev. Sir,

Referring to my conversation with Your Grace and Archdeacon McKay yesterday, I beg to outline herewith the policy of the Department with regard to improved day schools.

On many Reserves it is possible to conduct this type of school with considerable success, and a reference to some of the schools in the Province of Saskatchewan will so attest. Suitable buildings are provided, consisting of a dwelling, in some instances with dining-room attached, and modern class-rooms. The children are provided with a simple mid-day meal and the preparation of this meal rests with the girls under the supervision of the matron. The services of a married man and his wife are desirable; he to conduct the class-room work and she domestic science and field matron work on the Reserve in accordance with instructions laid down by the Department. In addition to the housing accommodation a salary of $800.00 is allowed; $600.00 for the class-room work

Dear Sir:

Your wire of the 6th inst. re the Fairford Improved Day School, and also plans of the proposed building, received yesterday on my return from Fairford. Canon Jeffery representing the Archbishop accompanied me on the trip, and we went thoroughly into the matter and have viewed this situation of the education of the children from every standpoint.

We spent three full days on the reserve, had a fairly full and representative meeting of the band at Lower Fairford, on Saturday the 10th inst., and fully discussed all matters affecting the school. After considering the question carefully, I have come to the conclusion that the best place for this school is about halfway between the Upper and Lower Fairford Day schools, where a beautiful high and dry site can be obtained. Both districts were represented by their leading men, and they agreed unanimously that the site midway is the best for all concerned.

In my opinion, and the band have agreed to this, it will be necessary to do what all our consolidated white schools are now doing, convey all the children to the school every day.

The children available for this school at the present time number 42 of which number 17 are living in Upper, and 25 in Lower Fairford. I have received tenders from 2 reliable Indians for this work and they have agreed to take the pupils to and from the school every day, the upper children for seventy-five cents, and the lower children for one dollar a day, so in round figures it will cost $15.00 per pupil per month to do this work.
reserve which will give you an idea of the situation, the school would be two miles from the farthest pupil in the upper part, and 2½ miles from the farthest pupil in the lower reserve.

Where the new school is located, is in my opinion the best part of the reserve, but along the river at that point for some miles there is quite an extensive hay swamp, which prevents the Indians building close to the river, and for that reason none of the band have built in that territory, a stretch of about two miles. There is also the question of the children who live across the river at Lower Fairford, the Indians there went a Day school, they are afraid to send their children to the present school on account of the river which is very wide at this point, there is also a very swift current, and it means that to be sure of the safety of the children, it is necessary for the parents to take the children over and back every day in the summer time and in the winter the ice is also very dangerous at many times during that season. If the new school was built at Lower Fairford we cannot figure on their attendance, and it will be necessary in any event to build them a school east of the river.

If the new school was built at Lower Fairford 25 pupils are available, if it was built at Upper Fairford 17 children are in sight that could walk to the school. In both places there are 42 and we can count on an average attendance of at least 30, if the pupils are conveyed to the school. The band have agreed to give all the land necessary for the purposes of the school, they are perfectly willing to hand over to the Department 160 acres at the point indicated on the sketch, and I would advise this, as it would prevent any houses being put in the near vicinity of the school, and which might become a nuisance later.

I also took up the question of moving the Upper Fairford school to a point across the river at Lower Fairford, and the band were very much in favour of this being done and will agree to move this building next winter to the selected point at a price to be fixed later. For the information of the Department, I may say that this building can be moved quite easily and
it would cost about $200.00 to take this building down to the site, the size of the building is I should say 16 X 24 with a small porch, and is all wood construction inside and out.

After giving these matters my careful consideration I would recommend that this New Improved Day School be built at the midway point, also that an annual grant be made for conveying the pupils to the school, and I would further recommend that the Upper Fairfield Day School building be moved to a point across the river at Lower Fairfield, as soon as the new School building is erected.

Canon Jeffery and the Archbishop will be reporting to you in a very short time their views on the situation.

As suggested in your telegram of the 9th instant I will get you an estimate of the probable cost of a building such as the plan calls for, with an estimated attendance of 35 children, and a staff of Teacher and Housekeeper.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Secretary,

I thought you might be interested in what I had visited Peguis Reserve shortly before my visit there. We had a long conference and when it was over, only one dissenting voice that a Church should be built for the present at each end of the Reserve, and that the Church Yard and Mission House should remain in the centre, where they are at present located. It was also recommended that a small portion of land, about one acre, be given to the Church at each end, and ten acres in the middle. It appears that the man employed to go round and explain to the people in regard to the voting, lives near the centre and used his influence against the granting of the land in the hope that he might thus secure the building of the Church at the centre near himself. It was a strange proceeding and I am told that the Indians now regret the action very much. Of course, this will put a stop in the meantime to the building of the Churches, but I am in hopes that in a short time the Indians will think better of it and reverse their vote.

Sir,

As requested in your letter No. 469929/1, of date April 16th, 1917, I made a visit to the Fairford Improved Day School on the 24th instant and you will find attached my report on the school. When Canon Jeffrey came up with me to pick the site for the school, we agreed after consultation with Archbishop Matheson to recommend the present site on condition that the children would be conveyed to the school, and that agreement ought to be carried out by the Department, seeing that they went on and built the school.

The school building is a credit to the Department, the site is a good one and very little remains to be done to make the grounds both attractive and useful. The Teacher and the Matron are both careful and capable and they can make the school a success.

While at the school during the building in 1915, I notified the Department that I was about to fence in forty acres with barb wire and two gates. I got out enough teakwood posts for this work but on account of the lateness in the season I was unable to go on with the fence that fall, and nothing has been done since then. This fencing ought to be done at once so as to enable the teacher to keep a cow or two and thus be able to give the children milk to drink. The cost of this fencing will be about $64.00 for wire and $16.00 for gates. If the Department will authorize this expenditure I will go out there in July or later, after my return from the Treaty Payments at The Pas, and see this work completed.

I would also like to expend about $200.00 more on the road leading into Fairford Station. I did three quarters of a mile in 1915 and this road should be finished. It is very bad in
wet seasons, and the Indians will work for their rations.

Owing to the high price of flour, $7.00 a sack, at the present time and all other supplies in proportion, the Indians here will have a hard time pulling through the season and this work in July or August would help them to get some supplies for haying.

The school was in great danger on the 14th, 15th and 16th of May from bush fires but was saved by backfiring. I would recommend a fire break, say 15 feet wide, ploughed around the school grounds to protect the school buildings from the fall fires. There will be about three acres of ploughing.

The room in the basement that was boarded or partitioned off from the rest of the basement for the purpose of keeping vegetables, requires boarding up inside to prevent the frost from getting into the room. This room is 12 x 14 and it will require 500 ft of shiplap, 9 pieces 2 x 4 16 ft long, two rolls of brown paper, and say ten pounds of nails to do what is necessary. Thos. Sanderson will do the work for $6.00. I would recommend that Mr. Hyson be authorized to get this material from the Armstrong Trading Company, Fairford, and send in the voucher for material and Sanderson's bill when the work is completed.

I would recommend that John Robert Woodford be given the contract for hauling the children from Lower Fairford at $2.00 per day, Thos. Storr the contract for hauling the children from Upper Fairford at $1.50 per day, and Robert Anderson be given the contract for hauling them from across the river at Lower Fairford to meet Woodford. All of these contracts to be for one year. With these arrangements I see no difficulty in keeping the attendance up to 25.

Yours truly,

There were present at inspection in the forenoon four boys and eleven girls. School was started by the singing of a hymn and prayer.

The Second Standard, two pupils, read fairly well in the Ontario Second Reader and can spell nearly all the words in their lesson. The second part of the First Standard, 2 boys and 2 girls, read well in the First Ontario Reader and also can spell any word in their lesson. The First part of the First Standard read nicely in the Ontario Primer and spell well all of the words taken from their lesson. The Third Standard, 2 girls, read well in the Third Book and are very good at Spelling. The A.B.C. Class can spell out of the Ontario Primer all the words on Page 17 and can also say from the blackboard all the letters of the Alphabet. At recess three of the larger girls went into the kitchen to help the matron get dinner. After recess all the classes in the school were taught Arithmetic from figures only to Long Division. This lasted just one hour.

At 12 sharp the fifteen pupils went into the dining room adjoining the school room and had their dinner. They had soup, minced meat, biscuit, bannock, tea, sugar but no milk.

At the afternoon session all the pupils in the room were taught writing with pen and ink in their copy books for one hour, and then
from 20 to 3 all the girls went for one hour to Mrs. Hyson, who taught them sewing, knitting, etc., and the boys for one hour went out with Mr. Hyson to clean up the grounds and work in the garden. From 3 to 4 all the pupils are taught drawing on their slates, scribblers and on the blackboard.

The class-room is 24 x 36, with 16 foot ceiling and six large windows. The pupils' dining room is behind and is 12 x 24 with 8 foot 6 inches ceiling. The wing on the east for the teacher is 32 x 16 divided into kitchen, dining room on the first floor and three bedrooms upstairs. There are also two small dormitories over the Pupils' Dining room. There is a full basement under all the building with an 8 foot ceiling and cement floor. There is a large hot air furnace to heat the building and a fifty barrel tank for soft water. The furnace heats all the building above the basement perfectly and a very little improvement will make the basement frostproof.

There is a small stable and poultry house 14 x 20 and three water closets. All the buildings are in first class shape with the exception of the stable which never got any paint on account of the lateness of the painter in finishing the main building. Nothing was lost to the Department as this painting would have been an extra. If the Department will authorize me to buy about six gallons of paint I will have this building painted when I go up in July.

The attendance at the school for the first and second quarters after it was opened was well over the 80 mark, but since they quit hauling the children from Upper Fairfield, the attendance has fallen for the last three full quarters to 12.15. If some adjustment and rearrangement is not soon made, the attendance will soon be nil. This school is in a fine position and can do good work if the Department will agree to pay a fair price to the men who will carry the children to the school. John Robert Woodhouse has been
carrying the children from Lower Fairford since the school started for $1.00 a trip and he has to drive every day over 20 miles to get and return the children to their homes. He has been awaiting a reply for sometime from the Department as to an increase, and Mr Ogletree informed him at the last treaty payments that he had applied to the Department for an increase to $2.00 a trip but up to that time had received no reply.

In the first start Alex Letandre agreed to haul the children from Upper Fairford for 75 cents a day. He turned the job over to Thos.Storr who brought the children to the end of June 1916, and then quit as he could not make it pay. Since the first week in July no children have been brought from Upper Fairford and in consequence the average attendance has been reduced by the number at that point. Thos.Storr has agreed to haul the children from Upper Fairford for $1.50 a day. This is a reasonable rate, and I would recommend the acceptance of his offer to start on the first day of July. Wm.Sumner, who has been hauling the children from across the river to meet John Robert Woodford's team, has not been giving satisfaction, and I have arranged that he quit on the first of July, Robert Anderson taking his place and job at the price of 75 cents a day.

Re. A. Iden's Child

On Nov. 1st I received a note asking for medicine, as I was out on a visit across the river to seek child. I went down to a settlement and saw the child on my return. He told me she had got very wet whilst out with her grandfather on Tuesday Oct 27th and had gone to sleep in her damp clothes. He asked for Calomel oil as his towels were working badly. I had several cases of sickness the same as he case, and Dr. Donald gave me, and also some Indians, known instructions to keep the children in bed and keep their feet up. I told Alex if he wanted me the next day I would go and I would come. I had no message till Friday (not enclosed) when I went at once, the child was very sick a high temperature was on and she was in pain. I did all I could to relieve her pain and told them to keep her in bed, and I would get the Dr. Whilst there although the her temperature was high she got off the couch to go to have her hair done, & as Alex said she was looking out of window a few minutes before she died. The Dr. came after she had died and made an examination, & took a statement from Alex. I am fairness to Alex I have not heard myself that he committed it was through any neglect on my part and went when he called me, & Alex
When he had not called me. This report I think you will find will be in accordance with the one the D has.

I am, Sir,

Your obediently,

A. Styron.

Sir,

Your letter No. 46929/1 of date the 8th of August was received in due course, with copy of a petition received from the Fairford band of Indians, which petition asked for the dismissal of Mr. Hyson the teacher of the Improved day-school, on that reserve.

I beg leave to report on this matter as follows. I interviewed nearly all of the Indians who signed the petition and some whose names were not attached thereto.

Mr. Hyson has a difficult position to fill on this reserve, seeing that he is the custodian of the destitute supplies, and nearly always has supplies on hand, when often the stores at that point are entirely out of flour, and the members of the band come to him and ask him to lend them flour till the Merchants get theirs in. He has to refuse them, and in consequence makes enemies of some members of the band. The last time I was at the school, one of the leading men in the band asked me to try and get Mr. Hyson to loan him a sack of flour, as there was none to be obtained at the Fairford stores. I explained to him fully Mr. Hyson's position as the official in charge of the destitute supplies, and that he could not on any account give these supplies to anyone but the destitute. Mr. Hyson has charge of the medicines, and is the one charged with the duty of calling in the Doctor in case of illness, if he does not consider it necessary to send for him, and anything goes wrong, he gets all the blame.

Last spring the Indians of the reserve cut a lot of dry wood without a permit from the Agent, and they blame Mr. Hyson for giving Mr. Ogiltree information on the matter, but Mr. Ogiltree informs me that he got his knowledge of this when he visited the reserve in June, and seized the wood some days later. Alexander Letander blames Mr. Hyson for his daughter's death, but I investigated this charge last year and found that Mr. Hyson was not to blame in the matter, and that it was neglect.
neglect by the parents of the Doctor's instructions, that really caused
the child's death. These instructions were given by Mr. Hyson, as told
him by the Doctor for similar cases.

I saw the authorities of the Anglican Church at Winnipeg, and
was informed that Archbishop Matheson is well pleased with the work
of Mr. & Mrs. Hyson in the Fairford district, and does not think that
he would be able to replace them at an early date.

I interviewed nearly all of the Indians who signed the petition
and I find that there is very little cause of complaint against Mr.
Hyson, and that not of a serious character. You will find a copy of
the notes made by me when interviewing the Indians.

Yours truly,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Stonewall, October 22nd, 1918.

Interviews with Fairford Indians re the petition sent to the Department of Indian Affairs, asking for the dismissal of Mr. Ryson the teacher of the Improved Day School at Fairford, Manitoba.

Councillor John Robert Woodford, says that he did not mean to sign the petition against Mr. Ryson; he told Gilbert Cook that he had no fault to find with Mr. Ryson, and says that he is a good man. He also says that it was Hamilton Letandre who told them about Mr. Ryson having sent word to Agent Ogilvie that the wood was being cut without a permit, and that this caused the seizure of the wood. He says that Archbishop Matheson gave them Mr. Ryson and they ought to be satisfied with him. Mrs. Ryson also is a good woman, and teaches their children how to sew, knit, and keep house. When they were talking this matter over at Upper Fairford, and outside of any building, H. Letandre went into the Icelandic Store and came out with the petition in a few minutes, and said sign here, sign here, and the most of them who were present signed.

Gilbert Cook whose name is on the petition, says that he did not sign it, and that Mr. Ryson is a good man, and that his wife is a good woman, and that he has no fault to find with either of them.

Alexander Letandre's only reason for wanting Mr. Ryson removed is that he did not act promptly in calling the Doctor when his daughter was sick about two years ago. The girl died and he still feels that if the Doctor had been called right away she might have recovered. He has nothing against Mr. or Mrs. Ryson as teacher or matron, and is sending his children to the school. (Copy of letter re this matter attached.)

W.J. Sumner says that he put his name on the petition because he did not like to say no. He likes Mr. Ryson, and has nothing to say against him, and as far as he knows he is doing well, he says he was urged to sign by H. Letandre. He also says that his brother John who was present at the meeting, signed the same as he.
Robert Anderson did not sign the petition, and has nothing against Mr. Hyson, and thinks that both Mr. & Mrs. Hyson are doing a very good work at the school, and on the reserve. His Father Harry Anderson who is a Councillor of the reserve signed the petition because he believed that Mr. Hyson informed Mr. Ogilvie about the Indians cutting wood without a permit. I am sending my children to the school, and would like to see the Department arrange to pay for the conveying the children to the school, as it was the first year. He wants permission to put up a small stable at or near the school, if he does this he will give his children a pony so that they can drive to the school.

William Sumner signed the petition just because he was asked, as for himself he knows nothing against Mr. or Mrs. Hyson, he was told by Alexander, and Hamilton Letander, that they ought to get a new teacher, and he thought he would sign the petition to have him removed. He thinks that the Government ought to carry out their promise and haul their children to the school.

Jim Thompson says that he signed the petition because the Chief told him that his children were not learning very fast, as for himself he knows nothing, he does not send his children to the school, as he lives too far away.

Thomas Store was at the meeting where they talked about getting Mr. Hyson dismissed, and heard all that took place. I heard them say that the reason they wanted him dismissed was because he sent word to Mr. Ogilvie about the wood being cut without a permit. I knew nothing this matter and would not sign the petition. I know nothing against Mr. Hyson, and as I live too far away from the school, do not send my children, and do not know anything regarding Mr. Hyson as a teacher.

William Woodhouse signed the petition because the rest did, but has nothing against Mr. Hyson, and does not know much about his teaching.
Robert Bruce did not sign the petition as he knows nothing for which Mr. Nyson deserves to be dismissed. He has known him ever since he has been at the school and can say nothing against him. He also knows Mrs. Nyson and thinks she is very good.

Chief Woodhouse signed the petition because he thinks that Mr. Nyson was meddling with things on the reserve with which he has no business, for instance, his writing the Agent about the wood that was cut without a permit. He says that this wood was dry and it was better to dispose of it, as his band was hard up at the time, and they had to do something to make a living. He does not think that Mr. Nyson is much of a teacher, and thought that a change would do some good. Robert Anderson told him that he was at the Portage La Prairie in the Indian Agents office, and saw the letter from Mr. Nyson to Mr. Ogilvie informing the Agent that the Dry wood on the reserve was being sold by the band.

Robert Anderson told on being asked, that he saw the letter at the Agents office, referred to by the Chief, and that it was as stated giving the information to Mr. Ogilvie that the band was selling the wood on the reserve.

Notes made by me on a visit to the Improved Day School at Fairford, on the 1st of October.

I found on the roll of the school the names of twenty seven pupils, classified as follows:

Total 27.

The average attendance for the year ending September 30th was 13.42. December, 15.93. April, 12.78. June, 14.27. Sept. 10.70

The first standard pupils read fairly well in the first primer, and are good at spelling. They can do small sums in addition, and are making good progress at writing.

The second standard read well in the 2nd book at any place I asked for, and could spell any word in their lessons. They do sums up to long division, and are good writers.

The 3rd standard read well at several places in the 3rd book (picked by me), and are very well on in spelling. In arithmetic they do all sorts of problems, up to and including fractions. They are also good at writing. I inspected the table while they were having their lunch, and I found the bill of fare as follows, Porridge, potatoes, biscuit, tea, and plenty of it. The poor attendance at the time of my visit, was on account of the children staying home to help their parents pick the potato crop. My dear Mr. Scott:

I enclose a copy of the petition which I received from the Indians at Fairford, which explains itself. When I was out there a few days ago the Chief and a number of others waited upon me and urged the combination of the School and Church work under an Ordained Missionary. I explained to them that the experiment was not uniformly successful, and that recently, where such a combination exists, I have had complaints that the Missionary was giving all his time to the School and neglecting his pastoral work. They persisted in their plea however, and the enclosed is the result.

I may state that some time ago I had complaints about the inefficiency of Mr. Hyson, etc., and I wrote to Mr. Ogletree who promised to hold an investigation and let me know the outcome, but I have never heard from him since.

My opinion is that the discontent arises, not fully perhaps but largely from a dislike to Mr. Hyson though I am not aware of any reason for such. He appears to be a pleasant man but certainly the attendance at the school is most discouraging, and in my address to them on Sunday I spoke strongly of the neglect of the parents in sending their children to school and told them that we white people had to make sacrifices to have our children educated and that they should do the same especially as the education cost them nothing.

In their interview afterwards they accused me of hurting their feelings by talking too plainly. My view is that the only solution of the difficulty at all these Missions is to bring the compulsory regulation in to force forthwith. I find the same condition prevailing in other missions which I visited and children are growing up in absolute ignorance, not able to read or write. With kindest regards, I am,

Most sincerely yours,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

CANADA

March 25, 1922.

Memorandum For File:

Mr. and Mrs. Hyson were appointed Teacher and Matron, respectively, at the Fairford Improved Day School, Fortage agency, in February 1916, at salaries of $600 and $300.

The Department turned down a petition of the Indians that Mr. Hyson be dismissed, in November 1918. It appears to be a personal dislike for the teacher that keeps the attendance low and the Indians dissatisfied. Mr. Inspector Jackson reported that the small attendance was caused by Mr. Hyson's unpopularity. It is stated that Mr. Agent Ogletree gives Mr. Hyson agency work, the execution of which has given rise to the dissatisfaction on the part of the Indians.

In April 1921 the Department turned down another petition from the band. The agent reported that Mr. Hyson had had trouble as Dispenser of Rations, etc., and in the collection of personal loans to the Indians.

In August 1921 the Chief and two other Indians petitioned the Department again, and were again refused.

In September 1921, His Grace the Archbishop of Rupert's Land was petitioned, and he suggested to the Department the compulsory clause to solve the difficulty. We informed His Grace that it might be advisable to have Mr. Hyson transferred, and Archbishop Matheson thought that the spring and summer of 1922 would give him an opportunity to place the teacher at another point.

I promised to visit His Grace in Winnipeg, in June, and to discuss the future of the Fairford Improved Day School.

August the 30th 1922.

My dear Sir;-

Acting in behalf of His Grace the Archbishop of Rupert's Land, I beg to make the following recommendations regarding certain Indian Day Schools within this Diocese.

(a) IMPROVED DAY SCHOOL AT FAIRFORD.

That the resignation of Mr A. Hyson be accepted, to take effect on the 31st of August.

That, in his place, Miss Olive Thomas and Miss Catherine McCabe be appointed Teachers of this school, the former to commence her duties on September the 1st, and the latter on October the 1st.

(b) OAK RIVER INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Inasmuch as Wilfred Westgate terminates his summer engagement on the 31st of August, we recommend that Mr A. Hyson be appointed Teacher of this school from September the 1st. We think it necessary to suggest that his appointment be for a period of one year, and that any extension shall entirely depend on his success in the work.

We are willing to offer the use of a large room in the Mission House for school purposes, and in lieu of rent suggest that the sum of $75 be paid to Mr Hyson to assist in meeting the expenses of heating for the year.

(c) LITTLE SASKATCHEWAN DAY SCHOOL (SANDY BAY)

We recommend that Mr John E. Favelle be transferred from the Day school at Lake St Martin and be placed in charge of the Little Saskatchewan Day School, such appoint-
ment to be for one full year, and any extension to depend on the results obtained. The transfer to take effect on October the 1st.

This school will remain closed during the month of September.

(d) LAKE ST MARTIN DAY SCHOOL.

We are seeking a good and efficient man for this school and hope to be able to nominate very shortly.

I should consider it a favour if you would let me know the salary to be paid in each of the above cases.

I am,

Very faithfully yours,

Archdeacon.
MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

On August 5th, in company with Archdeacon Thomas, of Winnipeg, our Mr. Agent Ogletree of Portage la Prairie, Man., visited the Fairford Indian Day School. My findings are on this file in the form of communications.

It will be necessary to employ Alex. Letander as Janitor, upon recommendation from agent. Mr. Ogletree promised to go up with the new teachers and assist them in establishing themselves.

R.F.
There is an improved day school on the reserve, which was built in 1916. At the time of my visit it was closed for the summer holidays, and I was, therefore, unable to examine the children. I, however, had an interview with Mr. Hyson, the teacher, who informed me that the attendance had been very irregular, especially during the winter months due to the fact that the children have from 7 to 8 miles to travel to attend school, as nearly all the Indians live near the Fairford River, and on that portion of the Reserve towards Lake St. Martin.

Sir:—

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th instant, enclosing a copy of a communication from Chief Richard Woodhouse, in which he requests that the teachers of the Fairford Indian Day School be granted permission to dismiss the children at 3:30 p.m. each day during the winter months, on account of the distance some of them have to travel in returning to their homes.

In reply I beg to say that, as teams are provided to drive the children to and from their homes, it is not clear under these circumstances why it should be found necessary to close the school earlier than the hour granted to any of our other Indian day schools. While we are anxious to do everything possible to make this school a success, yet we do not desire to create a precedent, and, unless a very satisfactory reason is advanced, we are not prepared to accede to the chief's request. We are aware that a number of the children have a considerable distance to go in returning to their homes, but, as teams are provided, this should overcome any difficulty that would be experienced if they had to walk. On very cold or stormy days, the teachers could use their discretion and dismiss school before the regular hour—first, however, arranging with the drivers to be on hand in time.

I shall be pleased to have a further report from you as to the need of a change in the Department's regulations in regard to the Fairford school by granting permission to dismiss classes before the regular hour for closing.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa. June 16, 1923.

Sir,

Travelling Nurse Lucas, in a report on her visit to the Fairfield Indian Day School, states that the children are dirty and covered with head and body vermin, also that they seem to be undernourished and poorly cared for in their homes.

In this connection would it not be possible for the teacher to instruct the children in cleanliness of body and to some extent see that their instructions are carried out.

The travelling nurse further recommends that the use of bread instead of bannock be furnished the children at their mid-day meal. You should ascertain from the teacher whether it would not be possible for them to furnish the children with bread and also if they can obtain at a reasonable cost a quantity of vegetables from time to time.

I shall be pleased to hear from you regarding the above matter after you have consulted the teacher.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

In reference to your letter of the 16th instant, No. I26-5-I.

I beg to say that when I received the report from Travelling Nurse Lucas last winter, I went out to Fairfield and examined all these children and found them healthy and well fed at the school; these children are getting bread and vegetables are supplied when we can procure them. Sometimes vegetables are impossible to get. The majority of these parents keep their children clean. I went through every house on the Reserve last winter, and found them fairly clean, with few exceptions. I have had no complaints from the parents about these children being underfed; the parents are well satisfied.

Dear Sir,

Having heard there is a special excursion running from Canada to London this year in connection with the British Empire Exhibition, I am very anxious to avail myself of the opportunity so as to visit my people in Ireland.

I am almost three years in Canada now, and thinking such favourable rates may not be offered soon again, I should greatly like to take the trip this year.

I should feel deeply grateful if you would kindly grant me the favor of an extra month's holiday; of course I would be willing to provide a substitute so that the school work would suffer no inconvenience by my absence.

As the reduced fare only applies to the boat trip, it would be a great boon if you could allow me the privilege of travelling at the two-cent rate!

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, enclosing a communication from Miss C. R. McCabe, assistant teacher of the Fairford Indian Day School, applying for one month's leave of absence in either June or September next, in order that she can visit her home in Ireland.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of one month's leave being granted Miss McCabe on the understanding that she will provide a substitute to carry on her duties during her absence. The substitute engaged by her should be satisfactory to you. We will continue salary to Miss McCabe and she should arrange to pay the substitute engaged by her. I shall be pleased to be informed later of the name of the substitute engaged and also the month when Miss McCabe will take the leave granted.

We are unable to comply with Miss McCabe's request to make arrangements for a two-cent rate from Fairford and return to the port of sailing.

FAIRFORD IMPROVED INDIAN DAY SCHOOL:

This school was built on the same standard as the school we have at Felly. It has the same living quarters and 1 classroom. A new school was built here last summer, so there are now 2 classrooms; previous to that, the dining room was used as a classroom. The

The senior room is taught by Miss Thomas and the junior room by Miss McCabe. There are 67 children on the register and on the day of my visit at the school there were 32 in the junior room and 25 in the senior room, a total of 57. The average attendance, I believe, was about 55.

Two vans are used in transporting the children to and from school, one from Lower Fairford and the other from Upper Fairford. These children are also supplied with a play outfit. An Indian who lives about two miles from the school acts as cook, looks after fires, etc., and a girl is employed in the kitchen to do the housework, look after meals, etc. This is generally an Indian girl.

I spent half a day in the classrooms and I was favourably impressed with the work that is being done here. I consider that Miss Thomas and Miss McCabe are splendid teachers and they are certainly very much interested in their work. They keep the children clean and tidy and take an interest in their health just as much as they do in their woodwork. They have a pony at the school, that they drive around with, and in cases of sickness they always give all possible assistance. They have also done considerable work in advising the mothers about keeping their children clean, etc. These two ladies are now in their fourth year on the reserve.

Miss Thomas asked me if there was any such thing as an increase in salary for teachers on an Indian Reserve, as she pointed out that they were still getting the same salary as they did when they started. Miss McCabe is getting $720.00 per year and Miss Thomas, $900.00. Out of this amount, some of them have to board themselves and the girl that is in the kitchen, Miss Thomas told me, stated that it was not just for the sake of getting more money but that even if they got a small increase in salary, she would feel that their work was satisfactory to the Department.

One thing I would recommend is that they be furnished with a little more furniture. These women are living an isolated life and I think we should make them as comfortable as possible. And when I see how well some of the boarding schools are furnished, I think the Department should supply them anew with the bare necessities—as most of their furniture is broken or worn out or broken, etc. Should the Department have funds for this purpose, I can furnish a list of what is actually required. The school building as a whole is in good shape.
The Inspector comments favourably on the Improved Day School on the Fairford Reserve. The teachers, Miss Thomas and Miss McCabe, seem to be doing good work and they have a large attendance at the school. I would draw your attention to the Inspector's remarks regarding an increase in salary for these teachers, and I am of the opinion that, if there is any way of granting the request, it should be done.

With reference to the Inspector's remarks regarding the poorly furnished condition of the living quarters at this school, I think, myself, that we should do something to make living conditions more comfortable for these women and for an outlay of about $200.00 we might be able to buy the necessary furniture. I do not know whether any rugs or linoleum are required or not; if so, they would be additional.

I do not think there is any Rural Day Schools run with better and with more success in the Province than this school. Miss Favell, as Cook and Kitchen help and Alex Letendre as caretaker are both good conscientious workers and leave nothing to be desired for the comfort of the teachers and pupils. The teachers have a horse, buggy and cutter which is supplied by the Department and are thus able to make regular visits to the parents of their pupils, which makes a very friendly feeling with the Indians and their teachers. INSPECTOR OF SCHOOLS, ERIKSDALE, Man.,
dated January 24, 1927.

You will be pleased to hear that all the schools have made good progress during the year. Fairford operating under most favorable conditions still holds the lead, but it is being overtaken by Lake St. Martin School, though Mr. Garwood works alone there with scanty equipment, unfavorable environment and a heavy ungraded school. All are doing well, however. Mr. Wheeldon, of Little Saskatchewan, has done much more efficient work this year and the school shows substantial progress.
FAIRFORD IMPROVED DAY SCHOOL.

We have two classrooms at this school, the Senior room being taught by Miss Thomas and the Junior room by Miss McCabe. There are 65 children on the register and I think the average attendance, when you take everything into consideration, is very good. Two vans are used to convey the children to and from school, one for Upper Fairford and the other for Lower Fairford. The classroom work at this school is exceptionally good as both teachers are well qualified. The teachers also do a lot of work on the reserve in the way of visiting and attending to sick, etc., and a great improvement has been noticed in the children that are attending school; they are keeping themselves clean and tidy. I think Misses Thomas and McCabe are doing...
are doing splendid work on the reserve and I am glad to know that the Indians appreciate what they are doing.

Their Christmas concert had been delayed on account of one of the teachers being sick and it was held the day after I arrived there. I think everybody was impressed with the splendid concert that was put on by the children. There was a huge Christmas tree and the Indians had donated about $116.00 towards buying presents for the children. The teachers also spent some of their own money in furnishing presents, as well as a number of the parents bringing individual presents for the children, therefore the tree was well loaded. The large school-room was packed to the doors, not only with Indians but with a lot of white people who live adjacent to the reserve. The concert was splendid and the children took their parts exceptionally well. In an address given by me between numbers, I took the opportunity of telling them how the Indians on the reserves in other parts of the three provinces were now making their living from farming and stock raising. I had many enquiries from Indians afterwards regarding conditions on other reserves.

I am in receipt of your letter of July 18th. Evidently Miss Feirservice has taken offence and sent the telegram without waiting for any further word from me. What happened was this.

Inspector Christienson called on me some weeks ago on his return from Fairford and informed me that he had almost persuaded Miss McCabe to remain on at the Improved School at Fairford as senior teacher. He seemed most anxious that she should be retained on account of the excellent service which she has given for several years past. Madam:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, tendering your resignation as senior teacher of the Fairford Indian Day School at the end of the present school year. Ottawa, June 19, 1929.

Most Rev. Sir:

I have to inform Your Grace that the Department has received the resignation of Miss C. R. McCabe, senior teacher of the Fairford Indian Day School, to take effect at the end of the present school year. The Department is accepting her resignation with regret, as her services were satisfactory.

It will be necessary to obtain the services of a fully qualified teacher to succeed Miss McCabe, to begin duties when the school reopens after the summer holidays, on or about September 1st, next, and I would request that Your Grace will nominate the services of a teacher. The Department would be prepared to allow a salary of $90 or $95 per teaching month, depending on the qualifications which the teacher nominated by Your Grace possesses. I would respectfully request that the matter of obtaining the services of a teacher to succeed Miss McCabe for the next school year receive your attention.

I have the honour to be,

Most Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Most Reverend Sir:

August 13th, 1928.

Dear Mr. McLean,

I regret to say that Miss Johnson and her friend have withdrawn from the Fairford School and I am finding considerable difficulty in procuring any teachers to take their place. Mrs. Susan Miller and Miss Miss Skefffield have offered to take the positions. Mrs. Miller as senior teacher at $950.00 per annum and Miss Skefffield as junior teacher at $900.00 per annum. They both hold professional second class certificates and have had over five years experience in teaching. I am quite willing to approve of their appointment, as we shall have great difficulty in filling the place and I believe that Mrs. Miller from her knowledge of the country, etc., and of the natives will be successful. If you approve kindly wire me, as these people might not be able to wait.

With kindest regards, I am,

Very truly yours,

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Most Rev. Sir:

I have Your Grace's letter of the 13th instant, informing the Department that Miss Edna Johnston and Miss Mary Wilton, who were appointed senior and junior teachers, respectively, at the Fairford Indian Day School, had not accepted, and nominating Mrs. Susan Miller and Miss Nina Skaftfeld.

In this connection I have to confirm the following day letter to Your Grace of today's date:

"Department approves Your Grace's nomination of Mrs. Miller as senior teacher at $95 per teaching month and Miss Skaftfeld as junior teacher at $90 per teaching month at Fairford Indian School for next school year."

I shall be pleased if you will inform both these teachers of their appointment and arrange with them to take up duties when the school reopens after the present summer holidays, on September 3rd, next. We are informing both the local Indian Agent, Mr. S. J. Waite, and Mr. Commissioner Graham, of the approval granted for their appointment.

I have the honour to be,

Most Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Mackenzie,

Some two or three days ago I received a letter from Anne Clare, sister of Mrs. Miller, the head teacher of the improved School in Fairford, informing me that Miss Skaltfield was ill and requesting that she be allowed to substitute for her for a month. Sir,

Re: 126-5-1

With reference to Department letter dated December 9, and further to my report of the 21st idem., I wish to advise that I visited the Fairford Day School on the 7th. of the month and found the school had opened that morning after the Christmas vacation. Five children were present in the junior room and one girl in the senior room. I held a meeting with the Fairford Indians that night and discussed the school situation with them. They claimed that the small number of children present that morning was due to the parents not knowing when the school would open, and that most of the children were on hand on the 6th. and had to return home. Few Indians were present at the meeting and a further meeting was held at the Little Saskatchewan Reserve No. 48A on the 10th. of the month.

At least 60% of the Indians and their families are fishing on Lake Winnipeg. The season on this lake opens January 1st and continues until March 11th. The general opinion is that if the Indians lived on their reserve and sent their children to school they would have to be furnished with relief. This also applies to the Indians of the Little Saskatchewan Reserve. The fishing on Lake Winnipeg has been especially good and the Indians are making a very good living. Lake St. Martin is now so low that fishing is only possible at the outlet of the Fairford River and the upper mouth of the Dauphin River. These two places are fished from November 11th., the opening date for commercial fishing on this lake, until practically all the fish are caught. Then there is general movement to Lake Winnipeg.

There are a number of children on the extreme south end of the reserve and a number across the Fairford River. The children from the south would have a walk of close to four miles and the children across the river about three miles. Previous to this year a van service was operated for these children.
There are 23 children on the register in the junior room, and I have no doubt that in the neighbourhood of 15 will now attend fairly regularly. There are 8 on the register in the senior room and the attendance should now average 4. One teacher is all that is necessary. Miss Brock, the matron, has her M.A. degree, Miss Simpson is teaching on permit.

The solution of the school question on this reserve is to move the senior school to a place near the river. This would take care of the children on the south end of the reserve and those across the Fairford River. The cost of moving would not be expensive as the work could be done by Indians. There would be no extra cost in the upkeep.

Dear Sir,

I beg to inform you that I am leaving Fairford on Tuesday Oct. 13th. I was appointed teacher of the Lower Fairford School and opened school Oct. 1st, but a sudden attack of stomach trouble, nervous upset and the long rough walk from the Upper School and residence combined has weakened me so that I dare not risk attempting it any longer.

There is no residence at the Lower School nor shelter for a horse. Several of the most intelligent Indians, also the missionary say they know it is too hard for a woman and it is doubtful if even a man would remain unless there were a place to stay.

The reserve is in two quite detached little settlements and part of the way to the lower one leads through boggy land that means knee-deep wading after heavy rains. All the road is rough and poor.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6232, file 510-1, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
The Upper School has large bedrooms, living-room, kitchen, pantry and furniture beside the large classroom with stacks of equipment, basement dining-room for the children and a good inside well with pump.

The Lower School is a one-roomed structure, moved from beside the residence a year or more ago. The moving cracked it somewhat but is to be repaired shortly. One end is partitioned off and divided into a small cloakroom and room for the jacketed heater. Circulation of heat is aided by overhead piping which circles nearly half the room. There is a teacher's desk and chair, a small kitchen table and a cardboard box of texts and exercise books. Mrs. McVigue of the upper school lent me some pencils and a blackboard eraser and chalk. There are desks enough at present but a cupboard or shelves would be a great convenience. There are four fine large windows in the south but very rickety and they have no blinds.

I went to considerable expense preparing for the post and am disappointed that it is beyond my strength and I hope no one else will suffer.
I am notifying the Synod Office (Anglican Church) Winnipeg, also the Indian Agent at Portage la Prairie of my decision to leave at once rather than struggle on indefinitely.

Whatever remuneration the Department considers suitable and right will be acceptable to me. I would be very glad if my fare could be refunded.

Yours very truly,
(Mrs) Mildred M. Smith.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Mrs. Smith, the lately appointed teacher at Lower Fairford School finds the walk to and from the School too exacting and has resigned as teacher. We find it extremely difficult if not impossible to obtain the services of a well qualified teacher who can give himself entirely to the work but I have called into Winnipeg today and have seen the Rev. A. E. Thain, a graduate of The Anglican Theological College, Vancouver, B.C., and the incumbent of Fairford, who came to Manitoba last Spring from Alert Bay, British Columbia, having had some experience with the Indians and also in teaching their children at our School there. I find he can and will gladly give Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of each week to teaching in Fairford School, if this agreement is in accord with the Department's decision. He is an excellent teacher, liked by the Indians and well able to teach the children committed to his care. If the Department will consent during the present emergency to Mr. Thain being appointed teacher under these conditions and until we find a full time competent teacher available for the Monday also I shall feel much happier in knowing our Indian children are well provided for.

In this case it will be necessary to provide Mr. Thain with a horse and cutter and also to erect a stable for the horse on the school property. Under these conditions I desire to know the financial arrangements the Department can and will make and also whether or no any provision can be made for the furnishing of horse and cutter and stable. In any event it will, I think, be necessary during the winter months to provide a stable for the teacher's horse.
At present I cannot see how any more satisfactory arrangements can be made than those I have suggested and I shall be glad if the Department can agree to the same. It is with regret I give the Department further trouble.

I wish to inform you of my resignation as teacher of the Improved Indian Day Sch., Fairford from June 30th ult.

Owing partly to my health and to my husband's absence from home, I felt it my duty to return home though very sorry to leave the work.

In my nineteen years work amongst the Indians 1921-29 & 1932-43, I can see much progress, rather slow, but sure and steady.

I have sent a report to Mr. Inspector Hamilton re: on the work of the Indian Effort Service Club which the Government asked Miss Buckley, Rolling River Mission to organize in May 1942. It is a splendid organization and a wonderful help to the...

Re: Miss McCabe, Teacher at the Fairford School - Portage la Prairie Agency.

In a letter from Mr. Waite, the Agent, he writes as follows:

"I feel that the matter of Miss McCabe should be taken up with the Department. This woman is around 60 odd years of age, is a cripple and only able to take care of herself. There is no doubt that she is an experienced teacher and during the war years when teachers were not available, has filled a gap. The condition of the war years in regard to the obtaining of teachers is changing and I feel that a younger teacher should now be engaged for the Fairford School. If a nurse is to be kept comfortable at the school, the services of a house-keeper should also be obtained. The house is large, requires a lot of upkeep that a teacher after teaching all day cannot give. The ideal setup for this school would be a married couple. This would eliminate the services of a caretaker."

If possible, I think a younger teacher should be obtained for the opening of school in January, 1946. I agree with Mr. Waite that the ideal setup would be a married couple; but if such cannot be obtained then the Department should allow a house-keeper. This is a large building and there is altogether too much work for a teacher. She cannot teach all day - keep the residence clean and tidy - cook and issue drugs. The housekeeper could issue drugs and cook also for the nurse when on the reserve. The salary might be charged against both the schools and medical service.

A real effort should be made to provide a first class teacher.

I submit the following report on schools in the Portage la Prairie Agency inspected during November, 1946.

FAIRFORD IMPROVED DAY SCHOOL

Miss P. Baron is the teacher in charge. She is a qualified teacher and is doing excellent work.

The register shows 22 pupils and the grades are as follows:

- Grade 1 - 14
- Grade 2 - 5
- Grade 3 - 2
- Grade 5 - 1

The pupils were well dressed and clean in appearance.

The class-room is large, well-lighted and tidy.

The outhouses are in good condition.

Some pupils have had impetigo and so could not attend. A few have been absent with severe colds.

It was much impressed with the work being done by Miss Baron. She is greatly interested and the children are making good progress.

This school is a large building and considerable time is required to keep it clean. This work along with the preparation of meals, teaching, and preparing class-room work is altogether too much for one person. She also issues drugs when the Nurse, Mrs. Raynor is working on the other reserves. I recommend that authority be granted Mr. Waite, the Agent, to engage a maid so that Miss Baron may devote all her time to teaching. As pointed out above Miss Baron is a qualified teacher and is doing excellent work but unless she can be given help I doubt if she will remain for long.

Dear Mr. Henry:

There were no children in attendance at the Lower Fairford School today. Perhaps this was due in part to the continued Treaty Day celebrations, but I fear that it is mainly because the Indians are opposed to having the school open during July and August.

During the morning session I was surprised by a visit from Chief Woodhouse and the three councillors. The chief approached belligerently with the words: "Why are you staying here? I am the boss on the Reserve, and we don't want the school open during July and August." Though taken aback by his abruptness, I informed him that I was hired for those
months and that I was simply carrying out instructions when I opened the school.

Apparently they didn't have the courage to approach Mr. Waite with their opposition when he visited at treaty time. Would you kindly cooperate by writing to inform the Chief that I am only doing my duty? Though I explained this to him, a letter from head office would perhaps be more satisfactory to him.

I also said that I planned to carry on in spite of opposition, unless I received different instructions from you. They seem to fear that the school will be open for the summer only and closed again in September. I assured them that you would endeavor to secure a teacher for the whole year.

Thanks for your cooperation in this matter! Kindly reply immediately. In the meantime I will keep the school open.

Yours truly,

(Miss) V. M. Graham.

Dear Secretary,

On Sept. 1st, I left Fairford Reserve. Though having met with opposition when I first opened Lower Fairford School, I was encouraged, as time went on, by the increasing enthusiasm of the children attending. Before my departure I believe that most of parents were becoming a little more co-operative too. I will enclose a note received from Councillor C.J. Anderson, who was at first most opposed to the idea of a summer school.

In order that the children may continue...
with their studies, I do hope that a teacher has been secured for the Lower Fairford school, as there is a desperate need. A teacherage at the lower school would mean a great deal to a teacher there for the distance from the other residence is too great for walking. If the roads were even fair, the two mile hike would not seem so bad. However, I'm sorry to say that the roads have long been in need of repair. There was so much rain in August that at times they were almost impassable. It was only the realization of the great need, and because of the eagerness of the children, to whom school was still a novelty, that I managed to...
attend each day in spite of unbelievable swarms of mosquitoes; very bad roads, often necessitating the carrying of logs to place across the water and mud holes before being able to cross; and the detours around the farm instructed non-too-friendly-looking, prized animals which were permitted to roam at large.

Might I suggest that a well be dug either at the school or the new residence which I understand is to be erected soon. At present the children carry water from the river. Besides the distance to carry it, there is always the danger of typhoid resulting from the use of river water.

At present, I am
at home for a few days before returning to Toronto for further study.

Aside from the physical discomfort, I count my four months experience on Manitoban Indian Reserve of very great value. Never having been on a reserve before, it was in many ways a revelation. If they could only become more independent, and realize that they could do much to help improve conditions on their reserve it would be a wonderful thing.

Instead, they seem to be resigned to present conditions and run horses and break wagons, but make no attempt to improve the roads. May the Indian welfare teachers help educate them to

Dear Sir,

My wife, Mrs. J. F. Knuckey, was engaged as teacher for the above school. She started her teaching duties on October 1st last. She finds the classes too small and the strain too heavy to continue teaching and hereby quits her position at the end of the Christmas holidays.

I am writing to you in order to make sure that my wife's resignation affects myself since I naturally gave up my school, the same reason she was engaged initially, on Oct 1st, at the same time. I am writing this before the end of the month and will send my letter by air mail so as to get it to you in time. I assure teachers for school re-opening after the Christmas holidays, and I further help you in any way I can. I am advising Mrs. Porter, Secretary of the Reserve Board, who does the advertising and receives the applications for teachers for the school. Similarly, I am advising Mrs. Knuckey, Indian Agent at Big Lake Reserve, whose agency needs reserve.

I would add that if a teacher is not secured for Mrs. Knuckey's school (the Reserve school) and a very necessary Sunday School is needed for school re-opening after the Christmas holidays, I would be glad to assist for a reasonable length of time, and even hopefully stretch this a bit, in order to keep the school open until you secure a teacher for it.

Would you kindly, in view of your resignation,
Take the necessary adjustments as to deductions from our salaries as & Income Tax and Pension Fund, that is to say, try in order not to make any deductions from the October cheque if have been not been mailed early when you receive my letter, and (have them) refund if they have been mailed, and to send that no deductions be made from November and December cheques. I make this request as Miss MacKay will have earned only $468 these bringing me under her unearned status clause with total exceptions of $1500. (Salary $156.00 per mo.) and as I shall have earned only $468. Neither of us will be earning after January, though, as far as I can see, this would not affect deductions by your department.

We had hoped to be of greatest service together, and this includes the people and children here. Remember - but where health is involved you will understand it cannot be avoided.

Personally, I express my regret we cannot have faced tomorrow.

Yours truly,

Telegram in reply to Mr Bean's wire July 30th, 1930.

F.T. Bean, Farm Instructor, Gypsumville, Man.

You were instructed to obtain prices on work of renovating. Work must cease immediately. Advise me the amount of work done.

Signed, J. Waite.
Sir,

I regret to have to advise you that the work of painting the Fairfield Improved Indian Day School was commenced on or about July 15th by Mr. Alf. Johnston, who resides on the Reserve. The first intimation I had of this work was by the Farm Instructor's letter dated July 28th 1930 and received at this office on the 30th. Copy of the paragraph numbered 1, is attached herewith. I telephoned wire the Farm Instructor and enclosed copy of letter in reply, numbered 1, 2 and 3. During Treaty Payments on the Fairfield Reserve, I requested Mr. Bean to obtain a price for the renovating of the school, from one Alphonse Johnston, who resides on the Fairfield Reserve, for prices on paint from the local dealers. Johnston gave me no information during Treaty Payments. I went over the building with Mr. Bean and showed him the work required, so that he would be able to give Johnston an intelligent idea of what the work consisted of. On July 10th I received a letter from Mr. Johnston, which, and from his letter I was able to furnish approximate costs of the renovating to the Department, by letter No.10, dated July 21st. On the 5th instant, I proceeded to the Fairfield Reserve to see what work had been done. I interviewed Mr. Bean at the Home Farm and he claimed not having received my instructions. My instructions were given to Mr. Bean on the 26th of June, on July 1st Mr. Bean left the reserve for ten days holidays, returning to the reserve on the 11th, in the meantime no written instructions were received from me and Mr. Bean admitted that it was the first time he had come ahead with work without receiving instructions from me in writing. The paint was purchased from the Ashern Supply Company, Ashern, this being the only tender asked for, although he has been advised in writing that he must submit tenders to obtain tenders for all supplies over the sum of $15.00, and to obtain written authority before proceeding with any work. The bill for the paint in the neighbourhood of $175.00 and the following work was completed: Gilding in one room- one coat kalsomine, roof- shingle- stained black complete on main building, cut-side of building- one coat on South and West sides, work just commenced on the North side, medicine room- one coat kalsomine, kitchen- one coat of flat wall paint, cornice at the top of buildings- one coat of paint. The work is about half finished. Will you please advise what further action I am to take in this matter.

Yours obedient servant,
Indian Agent

Ottawa, December 13, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, requesting authority to purchase a horse for the use of the teacher at the Fairford Indian Day School to replace the one which recently died.

In reply I have to say that our funds for the balance of the present fiscal year are entirely assigned. Would it not be possible for the teacher to arrange with the Indians to drive them around the Reserve during the present winter? Our new appropriation will be available after April 1st, next, at which time, if you again draw this matter to the attention of the Department, consideration will be given to authorizing the expenditure required in the purchase of a horse. Either the teachers or yourself should endeavour to make arrangements with the Indians for the necessary driving services in the course of their visits around the Reserve during the next few months.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of a requisition from the teacher of the Fairford Indian Day School for various supplies to be used in repairing harness, window glass, fire extinguishers, etc.

In reply I have to say that if you consider the supplies, such as entry straps, hame straps, leather, copper rivets and throat lash, to be required, you may purchase and have same delivered. The teacher also requests that 3 light sash, 21 x 35, and 2 light sash, 21 x 25, be supplied. It is not stated why these are required, but if you consider this equipment to be required, you may supply same and have it installed, with the necessary window glass. You may also supply the quantity of flag rope required. You should obtain itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of any of the above equipment.

Regarding the request for three fire extinguishers, I have to say it is noted that there are already two extinguishers on hand, and it is not understood why three extra extinguishers are required. Please furnish a report regarding this request, stating whether you consider that a further number of extinguishers is necessary, and, if so, the number you would recommend be supplied.

Sir:

Referring to that portion of your letter of the 15th instant, regarding the fencing of the school grounds and residences at the Lake St. Martin, Ebb and Flow and Waterhen River Indian Day Schools, and giving an estimate of the cost of the wire and labour required, also the erection of a verandah on the teacher's residence at the Waterhen School, I have to say that these items were disallowed in our Estimates for the current fiscal year. I therefore, regret that there are no funds available to carry out the above work this year.

Regarding new boxes for the school toilets at the Fairford Day School, I have to say that, if you consider this work to be absolutely necessary, you may arrange to have the boxes built and installed. We note you estimate the cost to be $25, and this amount should not, if possible, be exceeded. Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, informing the Department that new grates are required for the furnace at the Fairford Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the furnace at this school was installed in 1927 by the Gurney North West Foundry Co., Ltd., Winnipeg. On the voucher forwarded by this firm for payment they give the number and make of the furnace as follows:

Sir,

I beg to ask authority to purchase a new pump for the use of the Fairford Improved Indian Day School approximate cost $50.00.

I beg to say that the pump now in use is worn out and obsolete and no repairs can be purchased for same. It is necessary to have ice drawn a distance of two miles. There are a great number of pupils attending this school and it is very inconvenient not being able to get the water at the school.

Your obedient servant,

J. Waite
