Ottawa, December 4, 1931.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 30th ultimo, I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase and installation of a new pump for use at the Fairford Indian Day School, to replace the present old pump which is beyond repair. It is noted that the cost of this new pump will be approximately $50.

After this pump has been installed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I enclose herewith voucher No.B.653, amounting to $34.00 in favour of Mr. Alf. Johnston, of Fairford, Man., for work performed at the Fairford Indian Day School, October and November 1931, by order of the Indian Agent and installing New Pump January 1932 by authority of letter No.126-5-5, December 4th, 1931.

I might say that on the different visits made to this school by the Indian Agent, he found the old pump could not be used and he asked Miss Fairservice to have it repaired, which had to be done on several occasions until a new pump was installed last January. The Agent also found some of the school chairs and desks needed repairing at once or they were likely to be beyond repairing; he also found a number of the school storm windows in bad shape and asked the teacher to have same repaired before putting them up.

Trusting this will meet with the approval of the Department.

Ottawa, June 14th, 1932.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your Voucher C.87 for $107.54, covering amounts due Miss I. G., Fairservice, Mrs. C. Beate, Mr. Robt. McLean and Mr. Robt. Cook for services in connection with the Fairford Indian Day School during the month of May, 1932.

In future, you should forward separate vouchers, in triplicate, for services rendered by Mrs. Beate, Mr. McLean and Mr. Cook. In issuing cheques for their services for the month of April, it was overlooked that 10% should have been deducted from each of them. The necessary adjustments, therefore, for the months of April and May are being made now and cheque for $16.00 will go forward for Mrs. Beate; $25.50 for Robert McLean and $42.24 for Robert Cook. The cheque for Robert Cook includes the amount of $8.04 for the milk supplied for the midday meal.

As you are aware, the Department allows $40 a month for janitor services at the Fairford School and it is noted that, in addition, accounts have been submitted for $6.00 a month for scrubbing the school. Our funds are so limited this year that it is necessary to curtail expenses as much as possible and I would request you to advise whether or not the caretaker could look after the scrubbing and thus avoid the extra payment of $6.00 a month.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. Waite, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of the above noted letter in reference to supplies for mid-day meals at Fairford Indian Day School. During the past few years it has been the custom of the Department to supply materials for the making of soup on the reserves where a day school is operating; the soup is given the children at mid-day during the winter months. The supplies cost the Department in previous years in the neighbourhood of $175.00. The Fairford Improved Day School and Swan Lake Day School have been supplying the children with a mid-day meal summer and winter. I beg to suggest the mid-day meals be served at the following reserves during the winter as in many cases the children are walking a distance of from 3 to 5 miles to school.

Lake Manitoba Day School — 3/15 (4)
Little Saskatchewan Day School — 26.5/11 (4)
Lake St. Martins Day School — 40.8/15 (4)
Fairford Improved Day School — 49.9/9 (4)
Ebb and Flow Day School — 22.6/2 (4)
Shoal River Day School — 3/11 (4)

The cost of supplies for the above schools would be approximately $100.00 not including the milk.

A mid-day meal is not necessary at Swan Lake School as the children have not a great distance to walk and the Indians are in fair circumstances. The children at the Waterhen live close to the school and a mid-day meal is not necessary. By stopping the meal at Swan Lake a saving would be made not only in supplies but the salary of the Field Matron could also be eliminated. On a number of reserves a school garden is grown and the supplies furnished by the Department could be kept as low as possible. The saving at Swan Lake over a period of 10 months would more than pay for the supplies for all the other day schools where a meal at noon is very necessary as not only would the health of the children be endangered, the attendance would also fall off.
Ottawa, October 25th, 1932.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your No. 10 of the 10th instant, with reference to the cost of midday meals at the schools in the Portage la Prairie Agency. During the fiscal year 1931-32, i.e., from April 1st, 1931, to March 31st, 1932, our books show the following expenditures:

- Lake Manitoba: $31.15
- Little Saskatchewan: $26.51
- Lake St. Martin: $40.81
- Ebb and Flow: $32.02
- Shoal River: $31.11
- Swan Lake: $85.47
- Waterhen River: $9.84
- Fairford (incl. $20 a mo. for kitchen help): $499.93

As pointed out in previous correspondence, the Department finds it necessary to reduce the cost of the midday meal. Comparing the attendance at Fairford and the other schools, I think you will agree that the expenditure at this school has been larger than it should have been. During the current fiscal year, the administration of the services of the kitchen help, as authorized by official letter of the 10th instant, will reduce the expenditure considerably but this is not a sufficient reduction. You should at once take up with the teachers the question of reducing the expenditure for midday meal purposes to an amount that will compare favourably with the expenditures at the other schools.

The expenditure at the Swan Lake School is also high and, as intimated in official letter of the 12th instant, the Department will expect the teacher and yourself to arrange for a considerable reduction.

With regard to the other schools in your agency, the Department considers that the amount expended for midday meal purposes this year should not exceed what was spent during the fiscal year for which the figures are given above.

A decision as to what supplies are to be furnished will be left to yourself and the teachers concerned.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Ottawa, March 2, 1933.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of the requisition which you forwarded from the teacher of the Fairford Improved Indian Day School. You have not furnished any recommendation as to the needs or condition of the equipment asked for. Our funds for the balance of the present fiscal year, as well as for the coming fiscal year, have been reduced to the lowest possible point, and teachers in your Agency should only requisition in future for supplies that are of an urgent nature.

Among other supplies asked for, it is noted that the teacher requests 40 yards striped flannelette, 5 gallons floor oil, a quantity of stove pipe, 2 shelves for stove and an axe handle. You should report as to the use of the above equipment, and state if the quantity of flannelette and floor oil cannot be reduced.

It is noted that the school closed account in January, last, for a new axe and handle. Why should it now be necessary to supply an axe handle?

You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of a copper boiler for use in the children's dining-room, 1 package sewing needles and the quantity of white thread absolutely necessary.

Regarding refills for the fire extinguishers, I have to say that you may again purchase the chemicals required to recharge the extinguishers. When the refills are received at the school, you should see that they are installed in the extinguishers and that the extinguishers are placed in good condition and ready for immediate use in case of fire.

Accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the purchases which you are authorized to make.

We have no flags on hand at present. Another requisition should be forwarded early next Spring, when consideration will be given to supplying a flag.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

I beg to refer to the above noted letter, relative to the kitchen help Fairfield Improved Day School. In this connection, I beg to say that the teachers have continued the services of the kitchen help, paying her wages between them. I beg to acknowledge receipt of the above noted letter in reference to a requisition for materials forwarded by the teacher of the Fairford Improved Day School. In reply I beg to state that the stove pipes are required for the heater used in the basement. A number of the stove pipes became burnt through, and the stove pipes running across the basement had become shortened to such extent that the stove was too close to a lumber partition for safety. The two shelves are required for a camp comfort stove. These stoves are round and the teacher makes a practice of heating water on the stove, for washing the dishes after the children's midday meal, this is very dangerous unless the stove is equipped with shelves. An axe and handle were purchased for the school in the month of January, the handle was broken during the excessive frosty weather last month. Floor oil is sold in four gallon containers and is required as the school floor is of fir and is beginning to wear.

In my report to the Manitoba Inspectorate in reply to Department Circular of February 4th 1933, I stressed the need of undergarments for the school children and suggested that flannelette be supplied to the day schools on requisition. The underclothing could be made during the summer months and distributed to the children when the cold weather comes in the fall. A few years ago it was possible for the Indians to leave their reserves in the fall of the year and work during the harvesting and threshing periods and they would usually return with considerable clothing for the children. The last few years wages have been so low that it has not paid them to leave, the result is that the children are poorly supplied with underwear. I have suggested to a number of the teachers, that sewing classes be held in the school at periods during the week, in most cases the teachers fell in line with the suggestion. Flannelette can be purchased from the T.Eaton Co. at 15 cents per yard. The shelves for the stove would cost in the neighborhood of $3.25.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 1st instant, with reference to midday meals at the schools in your Agency.

Sir:-

Re: 126-5-5, Ottawa, August 8th, 1933.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of the above noted letter, in regard to mid-day meals for the children of Day Schools in this Agency. The mid-day meal at Swan Lake was omitted last year as the Indian had a fair crop and I felt that the Indian could supply his children attending school with a meal at mid-day. This year the crop was practically a failure and very little was left after paying expenses. Owing to this condition, I beg to recommend that a meal be provided by the Department this year, if the school teacher is prepared to cook same without expense to the Department. I beg to make requisition for $125.00 for the mid-day meal supplies for the eight schools in this Agency and a further $75.00 for the purchase of Dry-milk powder. The powder will cost .14¢ per lb at Portage la Prairie, 480 lbs being required, the balance of the money will be required for freight etc. The powder recommended is skim milk as the whole milk powder costs .33¢ laid down at Portage. A quantity of vegetables will be required as the garden at Lake St. Martin was a complete failure. The Shoal River and Little Saskatchewan Day Schools had a fair crop of vegetables, Waterhen Day School can get through on the quantity harvested. The other Day Schools in the Agency have no land for growing a school garden and a small quantity of onions and potatoes should be purchased. I will keep all costs as low as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, October 31, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, regarding the supplies required for the pupils' mid-day meals at the eight day schools in your agency.

In reply I have to say that you may incur an expenditure which must not exceed the sum of $200, in the purchase of the supplies required, including dry milk powder and vegetables. You should consult the teachers concerning the supplies required and apportion the expenditure equally in the purchase among the different schools. The Department will leave in your hands the purchasing of the supplies to be used for the midday lunch; but, as stated, the total cost must not exceed $200. You should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the expenditure for each of the schools separately, or you should state definitely on the accounts the cost of same for each school.

Our funds this year are so limited, that the above amount is all that can be allowed for the purpose of providing supplies for the midday meals. With the biscuits that have been furnished, the sum allowed should provide a fair allowance for this purpose.

I have also your letter of the 27th instant, stating that you have arranged for the van to transport the children from Lower Fairford to and from the Fairford Improved Indian Day School. It is presumed that the cost involved will be the same as previously paid for this service, viz.: $2.00 per day. It is considered that the driving of these children should be for a period of six months — until the end of April next. You should forward accounts, in triplicate, for the amount due for this service, at the end of each month.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

I have to advise that the drilled well at the Fairford Improved Day School has caved in and it has been necessary to haul ice a distance of six miles to keep the school going. I have had a well driller look at the well—only driller in the district—and he sets a price of $50.00 for the moving of his drill from Gypsumville, and states the probable cost of the well repair will be in the neighbourhood of $150.00.

The casing of this well has dropped to the bottom, shutting off the supply of water, the cave in being above the casing. I have had a man fish the casing out and clean the gravel out. The cost of this work will be in the neighbourhood of $25.00. A piece of pipe 4" by 24 feet long is necessary to fit inside the casing. I have asked the Cadham Hardware Co., of Portage la Prairie to furnish me with a price on this casing f.o.b. Fairford. It is necessary that this casing be put in immediately.

It was imperative that the well be repaired at once, as the ice in the Fairford River is now flooded, the water not being fit to drink and it would be practically impossible to haul water that distance in sufficient quantities to keep the school going. The lake, the nearest point where good water can be obtained is eight miles away, making a sixteen mile trip.

I trust the Department approve of my action in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

This school is a large building, with a full sized basement. It is heated by a furnace. Part of the basement is used for the children's dining room, part for a store room, and the rest as a furnace room.

On the first floor there is a large classroom, dispensary, living room, and kitchen. The upstairs consists of five bedrooms.

A second classroom is located about 200 ft. from this building and is used for the senior pupils.

Miss I. G. Fairbairn is in charge as senior teacher. Miss N. Shaftfeld is junior teacher, and Miss Pavel is cook and housekeeper. I understand Miss Pavel is paid by the two teachers in charge. Alex Letendre is caretaker and receives his pay from the Department.

The main building is in good repair, but some of the bedrooms badly need papering. They have not been re-papered for years and are very dark and gloomy. A new spring is needed for one of the beds - the cost should not exceed ten or twelve dollars. The kitchen oilcloth is entirely worn out and should be renewed. The room is about 16x20. A good grade of oilcloth is all that is required.

In the senior room Miss Fairbairn has 17 on the roll. I found 14 present. The grades are arranged as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| III   | 6      |
| IV    | 7      |
| V     | 3      |
| VI    | 1      |

The children were all well dressed and neat in appearance. They were well along in their grades and are making good progress. Miss Fairweather is a qualified teacher and is greatly interested in her work. The children read well and are quick and accurate in their arithmetic and spelling. They write well and I found their exercise books well kept and all work neatly set down.

The school is modern in design. The exterior and interior is badly in need of paint and the work should certainly be done this year.

Miss Skaffeld is in charge of the junior room. She is a qualified teacher and is doing splendid work. The roll calls for 32, and the attendance since the New Year has been good, ranging from 20 to 25. The grades are arranged with 27 in Grade I and 5 in Grade II.

The children respond readily and are not afraid to speak out and talk. They sing well and are able to do a number of song drills. I found no dull moments in this classroom and we are fortunate in having the services of such a splendid teacher.

A noon meal is provided during the winter months. The meal consists of soup, biscuits, and tea. Miss Pavel prepares the meal, but the dishes are washed and put away by the children.

The attendance is somewhat improved by the operation of a van as some of the children live three and four miles from the school. I understand two vans were operated until last year, but I am of the opinion that only one is needed.

This is
FAIRFORD IMPROVED INDIAN DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

This is one of the best managed day schools we have in Manitoba and splendid results are being obtained.

Sir,

The furnace at the Fairford Improved Day School is in need of repairs and cannot be used until the new parts are installed. The furnace is a Warrior No.65 and the parts required is the top casting of the firebox and one eight inch flue. The local Hardware Merchant has tried to obtain these parts in Winnipeg but has been unsuccessful and requires further information as to the makers name etc. To the best of my knowledge the furnace was installed in the year 1927 and was purchased either direct from Ottawa or the Commissioner's office at Regina. The makers name is not on the furnace, and from what I can gather the furnace is manufactured in eastern Canada.

I cannot find a voucher covering the purchase, neither does there appear to be any authority on file regarding the installation. If this furnace is manufactured in the east, and was purchased direct through the Department at Ottawa, will you please have the firm forward the parts as requested to the Farming Instructor, Fairford, Manitoba.

This furnace had been purchased from the Gurney Northwest Foundry Co., Winnipeg, Man.

I presume that this firm is still in business in Winnipeg, and you can, no doubt, arrange to secure from them the parts that are absolutely necessary.

EXTRACT from Inspector Beecher's Report on his inspection of the Fairford Indian Day School on November 27, 1935.

Original on File 126-5-6.

I arrived at the school at 9.30 a.m. and many of the pupils were there then. I suppose it is fair to presume that breakfast, in the majority of cases, was far from elaborate. At noon, these children received a hard biscuit and cup of black tea. Thus "fortified" they had to start the afternoon's work and the weary trudge home in the cold to get their supper - Whatever that may be.

This is a deplorable state of affairs and the many T.B. cases cannot be wondered at; in my opinion it is a wonder that this disease is not more prevalent.

I may be outside my jurisdiction in making this comment but I claim that we cannot get normal school progress under such conditions.
Hairston Improved Day School

Ottawa, August 5, 1937

EX'D.

Sir:

The following letter has just been received from Indian Agent Waite:

"I have to advise you that the furnace at the Fairford Indian Day School is beyond repair, and a new one will have to be furnished this fall. I can find no vouchers on our office files showing the purchase. Certain repairs were made to this furnace last spring.

I still believe that a wood furnace could be used in this school for quite a number of years, but an expert on heating should be allowed to visit the school, as the furnace has never been quite satisfactory. The old furnace is a 'warrior No.65'.

Will you please advise in this matter."

The Department does not see any necessity for sending an expert on heating to the Fairford School. If the furnace in this building is in such condition that it cannot be repaired, I presume it will be necessary to purchase a new wood furnace. You might consult two or three firms in Winnipeg who supply furnaces for this type of building and let me know the approximate cost for the Fairford School.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

5th Floor, Dominion Public Bldg.,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Dear Sir,

Mr. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, reports that the furnace at the Fairford Improved Day School is in need of certain alterations. The smoke pipe extends from the front of the furnace, passing around the furnace and into the chimney at the back.

This is not satisfactory and there is the constant danger of fire. The alterations required will necessitate changing some of the heating pipes. Mr. Waite recommends that McDonald Bros., Winnipeg, who installed the furnace be sent out to make the necessary alterations. The roads are open now, and I have no doubt the tinsmith will wish to make the trip by car. It will no doubt require the greater part of three days and the greatest expense would be in connection with labour.

I would appreciate receiving authority in order that the work may be done as soon as the fires can be dispensed with.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Ottawa,
June 21, 1940.

Dear Sir:

For some years past the Department has been allowing $2.00 a day for the period December 1 to April 30 for transporting the children from the Lower Fairford Reserve to the Fairford Indian Day School.

Has this resulted in the regular attendance of the children of the Lower Fairford Reserve? Is it necessary to pay for transporting the children during the same 5 months that we have in the past? As you are aware our appropriation has been reduced and every possible economy must be effected. It would be appreciated if you would give this matter your immediate attention and let me have a definite recommendation which, I hope, will result in our saving some money.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. J. Waite,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.
